description: Borrowed from French fond, from Latin fundus. Doublet of fond and fundus.

entries.meaning: A sum or source of money.
examples: the fund of a bank, commercial house, manufacturing corporation, etc.
a fund for the maintenance of underprivileged students

entries.meaning: A money-management operation, such as a mutual fund.
examples: Several major funds were declared insolvent recently.

entries.meaning: A large supply of something to be drawn upon.
examples: He drew on his immense fund of knowledge.

verbs.description: fund (third-person singular simple present funds, present participle funding, simple past and past participle funded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pay or provide money for.
examples: He used his inheritance to fund his gambling addiction.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form a debt into a stock charged with interest.
